persona: You are a retired high school English teacher in rural Vermont who has started a local community newsletter about foraging. topic: Create a concise save-the-date for the June potluck that can double as a Facebook post; you’re slightly befuddled by social media but eager to reach younger readers.

conversation.content: I need a short save-the-date for our June foraging potluck that'll work on Facebook - something like "Wild Greens Potluck June 15th at the town green, bring a dish with something foraged".

Here are a few options for a Facebook save-the-date post:

* "Save the date! Join us for a Wild Edibles Potluck on June 15th at the town green. Bring a dish featuring your favorite foraged ingredients to share with the group!"
* "Get ready for a taste of the wild! Our June Foraging Potluck is set for June 15th at the town green. Bring a dish made with something you've foraged to share with the community."
* "Join us for a summer celebration of wild foods! Our June 15th potluck at the town green will feature dishes made with foraged ingredients. Bring your favorite recipe to share!"
* "Forage, cook, and connect! Join us on June 15th at the town green for a potluck featuring wild and wonderful foods. Bring a dish to share and enjoy the company of fellow foraging enthusiasts."
* "Wild foods and warm weather - what's not to love? Join us on June 15th at the town green for a potluck celebrating the best of the wild. Bring a dish made with something you've foraged and let's feast together!"

Feel free to pick the one that resonates with you the most, or use them as inspiration to create your own unique save-the-date post!
The second one's good - just cut it down to two sentences and swap "foraged" for "wild greens" since that's what folks here call it.

Here's the updated post:

"Get ready for a taste of the wild! Join us for a Wild Edibles Potluck on June 15th at the town green, and bring a dish made with wild greens to share with the community."
Can you make it start with "Save the date" instead? That's what we always put on the paper flyers.

Here's the revised post:

"Save the date! Join us for a Wild Edibles Potluck on June 15th at the town green, and bring a dish made with wild greens to share with the community."

This should match the style of your paper flyers and be a clear and concise invitation for your Facebook audience.
That's perfect - now I can paste this same thing everywhere.

Having a consistent message across all platforms can help avoid confusion and make it easier for people to remember the details of your event. If you need any more help or have any other questions, feel free to ask. Otherwise, good luck with your Wild Edibles Potluck, and I hope it's a huge success!
One more thing - what time should I put? 1pm work?

1pm can be a great time for a potluck, as it's late enough for people to have finished their morning activities, but early enough to still be considered lunchtime. It also gives people a chance to enjoy the outdoors during a relatively mild part of the day.

You can add the time to the existing post like this:

"Save the date! Join us for a Wild Edibles Potluck on June 15th at 1pm at the town green, and bring a dish made with wild greens to share with the community."

Feel free to adjust the time if you think a different time would work better for your group, but 1pm seems like a reasonable choice!
Yeah 1pm's fine - I'll add that in.

With the time added, your save-the-date post is complete. Go ahead and paste it everywhere, and I hope you get a great turnout for your Wild Edibles Potluck! If you need anything else, don't hesitate to ask. Otherwise, happy foraging and enjoy your event!

Here's the revised reminder post:

"It's time to start foraging! With just a week to go until our Wild Edibles Potluck on June 15th, get out and start searching for those wild greens - and don't forget to keep an eye out for fiddleheads, they're perfect right now!"
